text_blocks.content: are certain "special circumstances" in which release of grand jury records is appropriate, based upon a court's supervisory authority over grand juries it empanels. See In re Craig, 131 F.3d at 102; see also id. at 104 ("The discretion of a trial court in deciding whether to make public the ordinarily secret proceedings of a grand jury investigation is one of the broadest and most sensitive exercises of careful judgment that a trial judge can make."). The Second Circuit has identified the following as a non-exhaustive list of factors for district courts to weigh in considering applications for disclosure:
Id. at 106 (capitalization altered); see also Laws. 'Comm. for 9/11 Inquiry, Inc. v. Garland, 43 F.4th 276, 285 (2d Cir. 2022) (affirming district court's application of those factors).2

2 The Seventh Circuit is in accord that a district court may order the release of grand jury materials upon a showing of special circumstances. See Carlson v. United States, 837 F.3d 753, 766-67 (7th Cir. 2016). Other circuits have taken a narrower view of a court's authority to order such relief. See, e.g., McKeever v Barr, 920 F.3d 842, 843, 850 (D.C. Cir. 2019), cert denied,

additional_notes: The document appears to be a court filing related to a grand jury investigation. The text is printed and there are no visible stamps or handwritten notes. The document is page 2 of 4.
